div.p: 1. IV:15. Friday.

Showery, Sultry damp depressing day. My face has been four or five days inflaming and swelling, till it became doubtful whether I should be able to speak or even to appear in Public next Monday. This afternoon the swelling abated— Charles as usual went to Boston, and returned to dine— My brother was here after dinner— I received a Letter from Joseph Blunt at New-York, which I answered, and I wrote a page of a Chapter for the next Volume
of the American Annual Register. My wife and Charles’s took tea at my brother’s. His daughter Mrs Angier is there, from Medford— I called in the Evening. Found Mr Marston, and Louisa C. Smith there— Home before dark— Aurora Borealis— In my garden and Nursery the plants were drooping under heavy showers— No new vegetation where expected— Gathered a few thimble berries, large as Raspberries, from a single bush which I had trained. Charles brought from Boston some poor Mazzard Cherries, and a fine Musk Melon; a present from Mr Brooks— He brought also the number this day published of the North-American Review; of which I turned over the leaves with a cursory perusal— It contains eleven Articles— The first upon the Laws of Population and Wages—a Review of three work by a Mr Senior, professor of political Economy at Oxford— This Man is of the Malthus School, and the Reviewer treats him as he had done Mr Malthus himself.

lg.l: Critics I saw, that others names deface
And fix their own, with labour, in their place:

div.p: this is especially true of the writers upon the modern Science of political Economy—the history of which from Dr Quesnay down would be a great curiosity— Of the other Articles, one is a reply to an Article in the Edinburgh Review for June 1829 against Mechanical Philosophy—one upon the Cherokee case, in which the writer censures the recent decision of the Supreme Court of the United States. One upon the Prospect of Reform in Europe— The writer commenting upon an Article of Sismondi in the Revue Encyclopedique, predicts the Establishment of Republican Governments throughout Europe— An Article upon the popular Sports and festivals of England—one upon Italian Poetry and Romance— One upon F. C. Gray’s Letter to the Governor relating to Harvard University. One upon the life of Henry Brougham, and one upon our Northeastern boundary question— On the whole the number is a good one, though bearing strong features of the bold and dashing Spirit of Alexander H. Everett, the present Editor of the Review.
2. IV:30. Saturday.

Mr Thayer called at my house this morning on his way to Boston, to meet the Agricultural Society with samples of his grain, in the Straw, threshed, and ground to flour— He looked at mine, and said he thought it would be fit to reap in about ten days— It has been much beaten down by the rain—but he thought I should have two bushels of it on the patch in my Nursery— He advised in the sowing of the seed, not to sow more than a bushel and a half to an Acre— He stopp’d again as he returned from Boston after dinner, but I did not see him— He had not yet settled the name of his grain; nor ascertained whether it was a known plant, or a new discovery— A Mr Turner came on a visit of curiosity. He belongs to Wiscasset in the State of Maine, but has been to visit his relations in the County of Plymouth where he originally belonged. Mrs Adams was very unwell all day; but rode out with Charles’s wife in the Evening— I sowed Strawberry seeds under the western fence in the Garden; where all of my wild Strawberry vines are planted— Raspberry seeds under the Eastern fence near Charles’s cropp’d Oaks in the Nursery— Thimble berries in the same patch opposite to Charles’s solitary Elm, and Mazzard Cherries with alternate Stones under the Northern fence, in the same row where I planted last year and where a single cherry, and a single peach Seedling have come up— I now repeat the experiment; and that of raising Strawberries, Raspberries, and Thimbleberries from the Seed. The Strawberry seeds I pressed out from the berries, separated from the pulp, and washed with Water— The Raspberries and thimble-berries, were crushed, and kneeded up with Earth, which I strewed along in a furrow not half an inch deep— Of all the currants which I sowed last Summer, one only has thrown up plants—there seem to be six or eight of them in one spot; but I have not ventured to separate them— I think I have also several blackberry Vines up from Seeds in two of the Book-boxes, but their growth is yet so slow that
they are not completely authenticated— I wrote to Joseph Blunt, and part of a page for the Chapter of the American Annual Register— But my time and thoughts are absorbed by other things—anxieties disqualify for action.
3. IV:30. Sunday.

Heard Mr Peter Whitney this forenoon from John 20.30. “And many other signs truly did Jesus in the presence of his disciples, which are not written in this book: 31. But these are written, that ye might believe, that Jesus is the Christ, the Son of God; and that believing ye might have life through his name”— And in the afternoon from Matthew 25.30. “And cast ye the unprofitable Servant into utter darkness: there shall be weeping, and gnashing of Teeth.” The first upon the Miracles performed by Jesus Christ, as Evidences of his divine Mission; the second as a Testimonial of punishments to be inflicted in a future State, not only for his sins committed, but for profitable duties omitted, in the present Life— Peter Turner had an infant boy baptized by the name of Peter Boylston Adams— There was a Collection taken to purchase an additional number of Children’s books for the Sunday School. Mr Whitney gave notice, that the Revd. Mr Buxton from Fayetteville North-Carolina would preach at the Episcopal Church, at Early Candlelight this Evening— Mr and Mrs Angier called to see us after the Service— I bathed with Charles and swam at the wharf— There was a Sloop, laden with Granite which left the wharf at the high-tide— Louisa C. Smith dined with us— In the Evening I went to the Episcopal Church, where Prayers were read by Mr Potter, and Mr Buxton preached from Luke 10.5 “And into whatsoever house ye enter, first say, Peace be to this house.” an Evangelical, and well composed regular Discourse—divided into Peace Spiritual— Peace Temporal— Peace Eternal. At the close of the Sermon he referred to the distressed and bereaved condition of his flock under the calamity which has befallen them and solicited Charity; modestly, and without importunity, as if to beg ashamed— Before the Service I went in to Mr John Greenleaf’s—where were Mr and Mrs Daniel Greenleaf, Mrs Ingraham their SisterLouisa C. SmithDawes, his wife and four young Children; Richard C. Greenleaf— I was occupied much of the day in writing a closing paragraph for my Discourse— At this late hour I absolutely sickened at that which I had written— It was gloomy, inauspicious, and affectedly rather than affectingly full of myself— The new paragraph, totally changed its character, gave to the future an aspect of hope and gladness instead of despondency—urged to generous and energetic action, and to calm reliance on a superintending Providence—leaving a slight allusion to my own age and proximity to my end, at the close; but merely to give additional Solemnity to the dying Sentiment of my father, and linking the perpetuity of Union with that of Independence pointing all at the same time to the future Prospects of my Auditory— As it is, my judgment pronounces the Peroration good— As it was till this very day, it was execrably bad, and I was utterly unaware of it— My self-criticism, was disarmed by the pathos of a close, in the last words of my father, and I had not remarked the aukwardness of manner in which I had brought it forth— How severe a Censor, it behooves me to be upon myself—
4. IV. Monday— Sun rose 4.29. Independence day— John 28.

Mr Seaver and Mr Elisha Turner two Members of the Committee of Arrangements for the Celebration of the Anniversary called early this Morning—gave me a Ticket for the dinner at the Town-hall, and informed me that the Procession would call for me here at half past ten— The Temple was opened for Ladies about nine— Mrs Adams with Mrs Nowlan and Mrs Pitts went at ten— Charles’s wife was advised not to go— From before nine there came a succession of visitors who engaged me in

Conversation until the Procession came and took me up— Mr Potter and Mr Buxton were in the procession, but Mr Whitney was at the Meeting-House— The procession consisted of the Quincy Light Infantry Company, preceded by a Band of Music—the Committee of Arrangements and Inhabitants of Quincy and the neighbouring Towns. When the procession arrived at the Meeting House, they were detained nearly a quarter of an hour— The house had never before been filled, an impression had been circulated abroad that the house was slightly built— That the Slate-roof was too heavy for the Granite Walls; and that the Galleries were not duly supported— Mr Charles Brooks told me before we left my house that it was circulated much among the People, that the Walls of our Temple would this day crumble into ruin—and just before we reached the house, there had been a loud cracking at the South-west corner of the Gallery, and a great alarm, among the Ladies seated there— Some new shoring was put under the galleries; and we entered the house which was soon filled to overflowing— The order of the Performances, was 1. Voluntary— Song. The Pilgrim Fathers; by Mrs Hemans— Sung by Coll. Newhall—with the Chorus—Glory to God in the highest! And Peace on Earth, and good will towards Men. 2. Prayer by Mr Whitney 3. Anthem Lord Byron’s Hebrew Melody— [“]Go forth to the Mount, bring the Olive-branch home.”— 4. Declaration of Independence—read by the Revd Mr Potter—Minister of the Episcopal Church. 5. Psalm written for the Occasion— My own version of the 149th. Psalm— 6. Oration by John Quincy Adams— 7. The Trumpet of Liberty—a Song— Final benediction by Mr Whitney.— My Discourse occupied an hour and twenty-five minutes in the delivery, and I omitted, about one third of what I had written— It was well received—frequently interrupted by applause, and closed with Plaudits long continued— The procession then moved to the Town Hall, where was a dinner of about one hundred and twenty persons, Mr Thomas Greenleaf presided— The dinner was too long; and after six or seven of the Toasts, had been given, alternating with Symphonies and Songs, I rose and said—Friends, Neighbours, and Fellow Townsmen—I will now with your permission, take my leave of you, for the present; and before parting from you, wish to add a few, a very few more last words, to the many, which you have already heard this day, from me, with so much indulgence— They are, first to thank you heartily for that Indulgence; and then to propose a Toast in honour of the primitive Mother of New England— May I add, the primitive Mother of those principles which have made this day, a day of Glory and of Joy— The Plymouth Colony.

To that Colony, our native Town, did not originally belong— But I see around me more than one, of those who number among their Sires, the fortunate youth, from the Mayflower, who first alighted upon the Rock— The Legislature of this Commonwealth have seen fit to link you in political Association with the District of Plymouth; and to that Association I am indebted for the honour of having of having been selected as their and your Representative in the Councils of the Union—an honour the more preciously prized by me, as a spontaneous and unexpected testimonial of confidence from that, which above all other Lands I am entitled to call my own, my native Land— Upon this day, I cannot forget Plymouth and her History— I cannot forget the Mayflower, and the social compact of her Pilgrims— I propose to you the following Toast— “The Root
The Root, struck from the Seed of the Mayflower; and the Plant ascending from it—Salutary—Fruitful—Perennial— It shall rise to Heaven, and Overspread the Earth.” This was received with three times three, and I left the Hall and walked home— There was a fresh breeze of air all day; but the Sun was blazing and the Thermometer above 90— I never experienced atmospherical heat more intensely than from the Time, when I left my house in the morning till my return to it after dinner— In delivering the Discourse, I began a pitch too high, and before I had got through the first page strained my voice till it broke— I thought I should be totally disabled from proceeding, but by lowering the pitch gradually found relief and spoke much more easily towards the close, than at the beginning— Degrand, Dodge, Clough, Child, Joseph Angier, and Edmund Quincy were here in the afternoon— We Spent the Evening at a Party at Coll. Josiah Quincy’s where I had some conversation withDavis the Son of Isaac P. and with George Whitney. There was one of the most resplendent Northern Lights that I ever witnessed.
5. IV:30. Tuesday.

I finished yesterday the version of the 119th. Psalm in 44. Stanzas, and this morning began that of the 145th. Psalm. It is perhaps impossible to make a spirited Translation of the 119th. which consists of a continual series of repetitions— There is a division of eight verses for each of the twenty-two Letters of the Hebrew Alphabet, and in the 176 verses, not one without reference to the Scriptures under the varied denominations of the Word, Precepts, Laws, Commandments, Judgments and Testimonies— I suppose only one division and its Letter, were read in the Synagogues at a Time— I have not been able to avoid some repetitions of the same line— I have gone through the Psalm in forty-four days—one Stanza each day. Of course Little Verve— I received this morning several Letters—one from my Son John at Washington of 30. June— The house had been entered and robbed the preceding Night—one a blank cover, Post-marked Providence; enclosing a slip from a Providence Newspaper, nearly three years old, abusive upon me for my controversy with the federalists— One from I. K. Tefft, with a duplicate of a Letter dated last November, requesting Autographs of my father and myself— He now also forwards a recommendation from M. H. M’Allister— Deacon Spear was here; I paid to him, and took up—W. C. Greenleafs two Notes to Mrs Lucy Webb; I spoke with him about the Sale at Auction, of the crops standing upon my unleased Lots of Land; and of some other concerns. At high water this Evening just before Sunset—I bathed and swam in the Creek; with Charles and Isaac— In the Garden and Nursery, the pignuts are coming up— Not one where I expected them, and always in clusters with other seedlings, making transplantation indispensible— There are two new ones up in the book box, fronting my window. The newspapers contain a long Speech, of Samuel D. Ingham, Secretary of the Treasury lately resigned in obedience to the President’s will— Ingham was received by a procession and Escort, and a concourse of People on his return home to Bucks County Pennsylvania— A public dinner was given him, and an address presented to him, by a Committee of Citizens, who requested of him a statement of the causes of the dissolution of the late Cabinet— This he declined, though declaring his approbation of the enquiry; but slyly alledging that it is the President’s duty to give this information
to the People; and generously offering any assistance which might be required of him for that purpose— They then requested of him a statement of the Circumstances of an attempt of personal assault upon him by his late Colleague the Ex-Secretary of War John H. Eaton, which Ingham had magnified into a conspiracy to assassinate him; and he accordingly related to them the particulars, which were in the ordinary semi-barbarian Style of backwoods quarreling— Eaton absurdly enough called upon him to acknowledge or disavow a paragraph in the Telegraph Newspaper concerning Eaton’s wife; and upon receiving an insulting answer, challenged him to fight a duel, which he answered by more insult—upon which Eaton did way-lay him both at the Department, and at Ingham’s lodgings till he left the City. The whole affair would be disreputable to any other Administration, but is strictly congenial to the whole tenour of Jackson’s life, and to the prevailing manners of the Southwestern portion of the Union— Jackson lived in open Adultery with his wife, from whom her first husband was divorced for that cause by an Act of the Legislature of Virginia, and a regular Sentence of a judicial Court in Kentucky— This was brought up against him in the late Presidential Canvas; but it rather aided than impeded his election— Her first husband had been many years dead— She had lived reputably enough with Jackson for the last thirty years; had become an old woman, with some pretensions to sanctity by methodistical regeneration. The Priestly propagators of the new birth took her under their protection; the White washing Committee at Nashville, patched her up into a very mother Cole, of Sanctity; and then the political Snakes hissed at the defamation of an innocent, and virtuous and persecuted female— She died at Nashville, just at the time of Jackson’s Election, and he of course held her up as a Saint and Martyr— Eaton had wormed himself into Jackson’s Affections, first by trumping up a book about him, called his Life, and in which he palmed him off upon the world as a hero— When Jackson came to form his Administration, he must needs have Eaton for his Secretary of War— Eaton had just married the widow of Timberlake, a purser in the Navy, daughter of a Tavern keeper at Washington at whose house Eaton and Jackson had both lodged— So it was that Fame, whisper’d light Tales of Eaton’s dame— There was much intriguing with Jackson at the Time to prevent the appointment of Eaton, on that account, but Jackson having brazen’d it out himself; familiarized himself with the infamy of adultery, and made the People of his neighbourhood in Tennessee as familiar with it as himself, fancied he could perform the same operation at Washington, stubbornly persisted in the appointment of Eaton— And such was at that time the rabid and putrid infection of Jackson’s popularity, that he would perhaps have succeeded in this outrage upon the private morals of the Country, but that Calhoun his Vice President saw in it an instrument for thwarting and discrediting Jacksons Administration, and of advancing his own popularity as the champion of morals— Nor ought in Candour, some credit to be denied him for an honest adherence to principle— Perhaps an equal or greater share of this credit is due to his wife, who from the first refused to associate with Eaton’s wife, and did not return her visit— The example thus set was followed by the wives and daughters of the Secretaries of the Treasury, and Navy, and the Attorney General, Ingham, Branch, and Berrien. The fires of AEtna have been burning in the bowels of the Administration, kindled by this Torch of the furies, and after many smoakings, and outflashings, have at
last blazed out, and swept the whole Cabinet away— Van Buren in this affair took the part of Sir Pandarus of Troy— Being himself a widower, tainted female reputation was but a haut gout to him— He constrained the wives of Rives and M’lane the new Ministers to France and England to visit Mrs Eaton; he prevailed upon the wives of the Senators from New-York, Sanford and Dudley to do the same— He pleaded with Mrs Donelson, Jackson’s niece and wife of his private Secretary, till she yielded, and he negotiated with Mrs Huygens the wife of the Dutch Minister till she proclaimed him a liar, all this was more than twelve Months before the dissolution of the Cabinet— The Self-degradation of Van Buren in lending himself to such despicable Offices, contrasts curiously with the lofty display of Patriotic principle, in his Letter to the President, tendering the resignation of his Office as Secretary of State.
6. IV:30. Wednesday.

Confined to the house near the whole day by heavy showers of rain— Mr and Mrs Frothingham were prevented by it from coming out to dine with us, as they had engaged. Deacon Spear came with William Field, with whom I agreed to lease for five years from 1. April last, with the buildings and lot adjoining to it—at a rent of 120 dollars a year, he engaging to expend now 25 dollars for fitting up the fences— A Lease is to be drawn. This Evening Dr Phipps, Mr Noah Curtis and Mr William Seaver, came as a Sub-committee from the Committee of Arrangements at the late Anniversary Celebration, to request a Copy of my Oration, for publication. A vote to that effect was taken by the Company at the dinner, and the Committee of Arrangements were charged with the execution of it— I consented to furnish a Copy— They made some enquiry whether I should be willing to let them have a Copy-right of it for the benefit of the Town; to which I readily assented— I told them there were some passages of the written Discourse which I had omitted to deliver, to avoid too great prolixity, but which I might be disposed to publish with the rest— There was something said about the printing; which I left entirely to the discretion of the Committee; but supposed it would take from two to three Octavo Sheets. My wife received this afternoon a Letter from John’s wife at Washington, with advice that they had recovered part of the Articles which had been stolen from the house, and lodged in prison the thief; the black fellow William Taylor, whom I dismissed this time last year here, for misconduct.
7. IV:30. Thursday.

Received this Morning a Letter from Samuel L. Gouverneur, of the 4th. and one from George Sullivan of the 5th. at New-York announcing the decease at 3 O’Clock in the afternoon of the 4th. of the Ex-President of the United States James Monroe; a man whose life has been marked with vicissitudes as great as have befallen any Citizen of the United States since the beginning of our National Existence— An Officer of the Revolutionary Army, wounded at Princeton in December 1776—a Member of the Confederation Congress— Then of the Senate of the United States— Minister to France under Washington’s Administration—next, Governor of Virginia. Then, Minister to France, Great-Britain, and Spain— Governor of Virginia again— Secretary of State— Secretary of War, and eight years President of the United States; elected for the second Term by a vote of the Electors unanimous save one, his life for the last six years has been one of abject penury and distress; and they have brought him to a pre
premature grave, though in the seventy-third year of his age. His administration happening precisely at the moment of the breaking up of old party divisions, was the period of the greatest tranquility which has ever been enjoyed by this Country— It was a time of great prosperity, and his personal popularity was unrival’d— Yet no one regretted the termination of his Administration, and less of popular veneration followed him into retirement than had accompanied all his Predecessors— His last days have been much afflicted, contrasting deeply with that triumphal procession which he made through the Union in the years 1817. and 1819— I went to Boston with Charles and paid a visit of three hours to Alexander H. Everett, conversing upon Political Economy, Free Masonry, and Nullification. Attended a Meeting of the Overseers of Harvard University; at the Council Chamber— Its only object was to announce the honorary degrees proposed by the Corporation to be conferred, at the next Commencement. Those of the last year had been postponed because the Meeting of the Overseers had been held less than four weeks before Commencement day. The Meeting now adjourned before one— I shewed to President Quincy the Vote of Thanks of the Corporation, to my father for the donation of the French Dictionaire des Arts et Metiers. 18 Volumes Folio— Lieutenant Governor Winthrop invited me to go home and dine with him; but I was obliged to return home to dinner— Mrs Edward Everett and Joseph Angier were here this afternoon, and took tea with our Ladies— In the Evening I called at Mr. W. Seavers, and gave him a Letter from J. H. Eastburn, the City Printer at Boston, proposing to print my Oration— Mr Seaver said that Eastburn’s proposals would be taken into consideration by the Committee— He shewed me a Letter from Richardson and Lord, proposing to purchase the Copy-right, and said that Beale and Homer, had offered to print an Edition of two thousand Copies, for one hundred dollars— He said also that Dr Phipps was very desirous that it should be printed at Dedham: and that there was a great diversity of opinion as to the number that it would be advisable to print differing from two to ten thousand copies— I said I thought the smallest of those numbers very large, and advised by all means that it should not be exceeded. He said that 500 copies would be wanted to supply the Inhabitants of Quincy, and that several gentlemen had asked for ten copies each. I said if the demand should be for more than two thousand copies, a second edition might easily be issued— Mr Seaver said the Committee would carefully avoid any measure which might be disagreeable to me— I received this Morning a Letter from Thompson and Homans at Washington, with a present of a copy of the Federalist in one Volume duodecimo, recently published by them—and one from Daniel Baker at Savannah, about my purchase of his house at Washington—
8. V:30. Friday.

I have been quite unwell the last three days, and especially so last Night and this Morning— The heat of the Season has been overpowering, and it operates upon me by a prostration of strength which disables me for all active exertion— It confined me to the house all this day, except a turn towards Evening in my Garden, and Nursery— Great part of it I was on my bed, and my writing was accordingly abridged— Mr Appleton of Baltimore, and his Son called here this morning— He was going to Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s and was himself so unwell that he could not alight from his Chaise. I went
out and spoke to him, but his voice was a mere inaudible whisper— He appears to be in a very advanced stage of a pulmonary consumption— My brother and his daughter Elizabeth dined with us and I had afternoon visits from Deacon Heman Lincoln and Coll. Stone, Editor of the Commercial Advertiser at New-York— Conversation upon European and American Politics— Jacksonism, Van Buren, Free-Masonry, Anti-Masonry and Mr Clay— Stone is himself a Mason, but has proposed and recommended in his Newspaper the formal dissolution of the lodges, and the abolition of the Institution— He thinks that although Mr Clay could not perhaps formally withdraw from the Society, he might with perfect propriety express an opinion that the dissolution of the Lodges would be expedient— Yet Stone discovers in his conversation an attachment to the Institution, which he disclaims and which he probably disguises to himself— In my Garden and Nursery I found a considerable number of the hickory Trees yet coming up— I remark the spreading of the Strawberry Vines, and other phenomena of vegetation for which I am utterly unable to account— My Apple Seedlings of the second year, stopped growing near a month since, and most of them look as if they would die—many of this Years Oak seedlings are now putting forth a second shoot— A pear tree, grafted upon a sucker bears this year for the first time— It is at least 25 years old— Bears full on two or three branches, and not at all upon the rest— The inability to trace the links from effect to cause renders all my observations useless— I cannot even tell why all my seedlings that do come up come in clusters which make it impossible for them to grow together— Nothing but the Peach-trees, and those in one of the patches at the bottom of the Nursery, comes up in Rows as I planted them— Of Oaks from the Acorn, there are not ten up in the Nursery— Every thing but the walnuts has ceased coming up; and they appear in very different forms, their first leaves differing so much that one could not imagine them to be the same kind of tree.
9. IV:30. Saturday.

The Tide was up between 11. and 12 this Morning, and I bathed at the wharf with Isaac H. Adams; but the water was so cold that I swam only half way to the lower wharf and returned— The Moon was in Perigee Thursday, and this was the day of the New Moon; which accounts for the high Tides and probably for the coldness of the Water. I answered the Letter of Thompson and Homans; and Charles brought me out from Boston a Letter from General Dearborn, and a Diploma as honorary member of the horticultural Society. I received also a Letter from R. Rush, who has heard from Mr Clay and his friends at Philadelphia— Clay declines giving away any countenance to Antimasonry. This afternoon Mr Mann and Mr Tolman, Printers of the Dedham Gazette came and informed me that they had applied for the printing of my Oration— Dr Phipps the Chairman of the Committee of Arrangements he said had informed them that I had given the copy to the Inhabitants of Quincy, and that the agreement for the printing must be with them— I told them that I should be perfectly satisfied if the work should be done by them— My brothers daughter Elizabeth, and Miss Susan Harrod dined with us. I visited my Garden and Nursery and observed the growth of the weeds—nearly all that there was to observe. I read in the sixth Volume of the Transactions of the Horticultural Society a very good Article by John Frederic Daniell upon climate considered with regard to Horticulture— It is a dissertation upon the raising and naturalizing the Plants of warm Latitudes in cold ones, and in treating of the temperature of Green-houses and hot-houses, insists upon the importance not only of heat and light but of relative dryness and moisture in the atmosphere—
shewing that for the artificial cultivation of plants under glass the hygrometer is an instrument perhaps more important than the thermometer— The writer mentions his Meteorological Essays, and speaks with high commendation of Dr Wells’s Essay upon dew— The injurious effects of cold occur chiefly in hollow places, and frosts are less severe upon hills than in neighbouring plains— “The advantages of placing a garden upon a gentle slope must be hence very apparent, a running stream at its foot would secure the further benefit of a contiguous surface, not liable to refrigeration, and would prevent any injurious stagnation of the air”— The ground Northward of my house is made by Nature, as if on purpose, for a garden, upon this theory— He says that the experiment of keeping the floor of the hot-house continually wet has been tried at the Society’s Garden, at his suggestion with great success— He proposes the keeping of Registers of the State of the climate both in houses, and out of doors.— I finished the 145th. Psalm.
10. IV:30. Sunday.

Sudden and great change of weather— Cool— Heard Mr Whitney— Morning from Ephesians 5.16. “Redeeming the time”—and afternoon from 2. Corinthians 5.11. “Knowing therefore the Terror of the Lord, we persuade men.”— The preciousness of Time, and the duty of redeeming it are common-place Topics, but the afternoon discourse, on the Terror of the Lord, was upon the doctrine of a future State of retribution— The System of the Universalists is becoming the favourite religion— They suppose a future State; but no future punishment— All hope, and no fear. This is about as rational as phrenology— Human ratiocination makes what it pleases of human language— The Universalists profess to believe the Bible— So does Mr Whitney— So do the Calvinists—and so does the Pope at Rome— Mr Whitney thinks it a delightful creed that the whole human race are destined to ultimate Salvation and happiness—he hopes, but dares not absolutely believe it— The Scriptures bear decisive testimony to human depravity, and they threaten severe future judgments to a very large portion of the race of man— It is impossible to settle in any rational belief of futurity, but by recurring to the Scriptures— The desire of endless existence is implanted in the human heart; and arguments for believing it, are within the compass of human Reason. But the adverse arguments are at least equally powerful and equal opposite weights in mind as well as in matter, destroy each other— There is left therefore nothing but the desire, as the foundation for the belief— To bring life and immortality to light was the professed and avowed object of the Mission of Christ; and he brought it as glad tidings of great joy, to all people— But he certainly did denounce terrible punishments to the wicked, and I see not how those who disbelieve the denunciations can believe the promises. Lord Bacon says he had rather believe all the fables in the legend, and the Talmud, and the Alcoran, than that this universal frame is without a mind— He had rather—that is the foundation of his belief is desire, not reason; Passion, not judgment— And this is the foundation of all religious belief— In the Evening I attended at the Episcopal Church and heard Bishop Griswold from Deuteronomy 29.29 “The secret things belong unto the Lord our God: but those things which are revealed, belong unto us, and to our children for ever, that we may do all the words of this Law.” This was an ingenious discourse upon the Trinity— The Bishop said the Church was unfairly and untruly charged, with requiring the belief of things not contained in the Scriptures. The Church required no such thing; but if the Scriptures said he, declare that in Christ, dwelleth the fulness of the father bodily; believe it—and then he gave a succession of all the texts which countenance the Trinitarian creed, putting them all hypothetically, and adding at the close of each text—believe it— To which with not less ingenuity he subjoined, if there
be any thing irrational or absurd required by the Church on Articles of Faith, it is not in the Scriptures. Now this is plausible but not sound Logic— The Unitarians might quote all the Texts which recognize the inferiority of Christ to God, and require of their auditory to believe them— The Unitarians might say the Doctrine of the Trinity is absurd, and therefore is not in Scripture— Arguments which may be adduced with equal force on both sides of a question can not be conclusive in favour of either— The Bishop’s manner of delivery is not very animated, nor absolutely cold— I called at my brother’s before going to Church and saw Louisa C. Smith there. Elizabeth and Isaac, with Mr Gourgas and Susan Harrod, had just returned from a visit to Mrs. Angier at Medford. [symbols]
11. IV:45. Monday— Sun rose 4:32— My birth day— My age 64.

My brother and his family, Susan Harrod, and Louisa C. Smith dined with us, at the invitation of my dear wife, in honour of my birth day. Mr James H. Foster, his wife and three daughters came out from Boston on a visit this afternoon— I had received yesterday a written invitation from Dr Abner Phelps, to attend this afternoon at half past four O’Clock, at the delivery of an Anti-masonic Oration by Mr Timothy Fuller— I accordingly went in with John Kirke— When I arrived, I was met at the door of Faneuil Hall, by the Sheriff of the County, Mr Charles P. Sumner, who introduced me to a Seat in the Hall at the right hand of Mr Fuller— At his left was Dr Beecher the Clergyman, then opening the Meeting with Prayer— Mr Fuller’s Oration took about three quarters of an hour in the delivery; and was succeeded by the reading of a Salter from Mr Rush of 22 folio-pages; in answer to one addressed to him by a Committee of the late Anti-Masonic Convention in Boston— It was read by a young man named Walker, but he was not familiar with the hand writing, and did not read it impressively— The Oration and the Letter were both ardent against the Institution— The most stirring passage in Rush’s Letter is the Statement that not one of the men convicted in the State of New-York, of agency in the kidnapping of Morgan has been expelled from the Lodge to which he belongs— When I went in to Faneuil Hall, it was well filled but not crowded— There were many indifferent Spectators some of whom were continually going away, and in the midst of the reading of Mr Rush’s Letter, a parading Militia Company, marched with drum and fife in the Street by the Hall which drew off certainly more than a hundred of the Auditory. Some of the Anti-masons seemed to think this was purposely done; but it might be otherwise— Of my Boston acquaintance I saw very few— Of the Aristocracy, not one. There were a few Ladies—not more than twenty— There is scarcely any popular feeling on the subject; a large body of mechanics being employed upon the building of a Magnificent Masonic Hall— The application of a blister upon the bosom of the public is wanting— A Melodrame— A Transparency a popular ballad well composed would run like wild fire; but there is no dramatist, Painter, or ballad-monger to produce it— Mr John Bailey was there; I took to town, and gave him the recommendatory Letter to Mr Gallatin which he had requested, and with which I had enclosed his pamphlet on the Rights of Governments— He said he wished
for some conversation with me, and finding we could not conveniently hold it there, I agreed to stop at his house on my way home— He rode home with Mr Joseph Morton, and I reached his house before them. I walked back and met them, when Mr Bailey left Mr Morton’s Chaise and joined me. He said Stone the Editor of the New-York Commercial Advertiser, wished me to write a Series of Essays, five or six in number, exposing the present condition of the Country to be published in his paper, but under an injunction of secrecy. I told Mr Bailey, that he might say in answer to Mr Stone, that my engagements did not allow me time to comply with his request—but I said there was another difficulty in the way— Mr Stone and I might perhaps not differ about the evil—but we should about the remedy; and such Essays, as I should write would not suit him— I added that I was informed by Mr Rush that Mr Clay declined all concession to Anti-Masonry, and that I thought Mr Clay was in secret Masonic Communication, with the Masons, his supporters— I further observed that if the Anti-masons, did not propose to support Mr Clay, it was of the last importance to them to communicate with each other in the different States upon the Candidate to be assumed by them, before their contemplated meeting at Baltimore in September: else they would certainly disagree there— The fiend would creep into the fold; turn them to his own use. They would break up in discord, and not only have no common candidate but would irretrievably ruin their cause— They ought in my opinion without a second thought take up Rush— Mr Bailey said he had hoped I should be their Candidate— I told him I had not the slightest desire to be so, and wished not even to be thought of— It was near ten at Night when I reached home— The Evening very cold. I found Mr Nicklin with his wife and daughter had been here, and he had left for me; a Letter from Mr Southard. He said he had also a verbal message to deliver me from him, and expressed a strong wish to see me— He had said the same thing to me on the fourth, at the Meeting-house, immediately after I finished my Oration— I was much surprized to see him there, not having before known that he was absent from Philadelphia. My wheat from Solomon Thayer’s seed was reaped this day.
12. V. Tuesday.

Charles was very unexpectedly detained in Boston at dinner, to attend the funeral of Thomas Welsh, who died very suddenly the day before yesterday. Charles is so regular and punctual, in coming out to dinner that we were very anxious lest some accident should have befallen him, till Mr and Mrs Frothingham came out, and told us the cause of his detention— The death of Thomas Welsh, deeply affected my feelings— His mother was first Cousin to mine, and from my childhood there had been a great intimacy between them. I lived four years in his father’s family, when he was a boy at School— Trying, critical and agitated years of my youth—when the world was all before me, and Providence my guide— He was afterwards four years my Secretary at Berlin—since which he had passed through various vicissitudes of Fortune, prosperous and adverse— Five short years since he was an Alderman of the City of Boston—a Member of the Senate of the Commonwealth, in affluent Circumstances, very popular in the City, and with a fair prospect of succeeding Mr Quincy, as the Mayor— All was since reversed— He had lost his property and become insolvent— Lost the favour of his fellow Citizens; his Seats in the Senate and the City Government—been compelled to break up the domestic establishment in which he had lived with his aged father, and his maiden Sister, and to live himself at a boarding house— His father died some time last Spring. He was however in the practice of the Law, which was giving him a comfortable support. He leaves two orphan Children, a Sister, and a brother helpless, and who must suffer by his loss—
The consideration of the misfortunes of Doctor Welsh and his family, afflict me deeply. Continued, increasing infirmities, ending in death I know are the allotment of old age— Must the prostration and ruin of all ones friends be added to the cup of bitterness? May I bear with fortitude that which I am doomed to feel— Charles came out immediately after the funeral. Mr and Mrs Frothingham took tea here— Deacon Spear came to speak of my Salt-marsh Land upon which he proposed to sell at auction the grass standing— He took me to task severely too, for my attendance at Mr Fuller’s Anti-Masonic Oration, of which he said Captain John Whitney had informed him— They are both unfortunate members of the Craft— Eliakim Turner came this Evening from Mr Adam Curtis to inquire if I would sell a half-Acre of Land, for a house-Lot, adjoining him—and if so—for my price—I told him yes—600 dollars— I looked into the Volumes of Massillon’s Panegyrics and Funeral Eulogies—and read part of the Eloge upon the Archbishop of Vienne, Villars and of the Panegyric upon John the Baptist. Massillon’s applications of scriptural allusions are always figurative and fanciful— They sparkle like the waves of the Sea at Night with a brisk Easterly breeze— In the garden [symbols]
13. IV:40. Wednesday.

I wrote to Dr Waterhouse, inviting him to come and dine with us next Saturday— My health was drooping, and furnished me an apology too eagerly seized for inactivity— Mr Seaver the Town Schoolmaster, and Secretary to the Committee of Arrangements for the celebration of the 4th. sent for the copy of my Oration, which he was to take to the Printer at Boston— I sent it accordingly; a copy of the whole discourse, as I had written it—to which I added a copy of my version of the 149th. Psalm, sung by the Choir, immediately before I spoke— Thus goes into the world my third Independence day Rhapsody, to be like the second lacerated, and cut to pieces by the Critics, after having been received with the warmest approbation by the auditory— Benjamin Bass came and paid me a year’s interest upon his bond—and I consented again to postpone the payment of the portion of principal which became now payable— Benjamin gave me also some useful information concerning the planting of apple trees, and of Potatoes; operations in which he claims to be eminently successful— The great error in setting out Apple-trees he says is in setting their Roots too deep. They should be altogether superficial—barely covered with earth— This accords with my experience. He says that varieties of the Potato must be raised by planting the tops— In the Garden this afternoon I planted the seeds of two Atherton Crab Apples, which had been kept over Winter and found and brought to me a few days since— They are withered up, but the seeds are in perfect order— I shall now see whether they will come up, and live through the next Winter. I have accumulating Evidence that the seeds most superficially planted are the first to come up, but that their growth is surprizingly more vigorous and rapid than that of any others— All my Strawberry Vines are running. I have also several Blackberry Vines, and two or three Currants coming up from Seeds sown last Summer— Mrs Adams and Charles’s wife took tea at my brothers where we afterwards joined them. Louisa C. Smith was there— After returning home, I read in the National Intelligencer, the Reports of the Celebrations of Independence day at Washington— There were two— The Official Diplomatic, Administration party; and the Clay celebration— There are said to have been nearly 400 persons at the latter at which the Toasts were wormwood and gall— Fendall was the Clay Orator and Francis S. Key the Jacksonian. At the Administration dinner, the Ministers of France and Portugal were invited guests, and Torlade the Representative of Don Miguel, addressed the Company in a Speech.
14. IV. Thursday.

Confined to the house the whole day by Rain. I received this morning a Letter from Mr John Marston, mentioning that he had been requested by the Committee of Arrangements of the recent Anniversary Celebration, to prepare a notice of it for publication in the Newspaper; and requesting a copy of my observations, on taking leave of the company at the table, after dinner— I answered his Letter, with the copy asked by him— I received Letters also from my Son John; with enclosed orders upon M’Lellan, Ballister and Co. Rice and Thaxter, and Cazenove and Co. Boston—and some other Papers—from George Sullivan. From Joseph Blunt—and a very curious one from William Barnes; a man with whom I have no acquaintance—but dated at Cincinnati Ohio— Alpheus Spear was here this afternoon and shewed me the return he had made to the Assessors of the taxable property at Mount Wollaston— There is this year a new Valuation, in the Commonwealth, and new Assessments are to be made under it— Spear spoke also of mowing or reaping the grass, growing upon the border round the Apple Orchard which I set out last fall, and overshadowing the seedling forest trees from the Nuts and Acorns then planted— I also told him, I wanted him to sow the grain raised from the seed which I got two years ago, from Solomon Thayer, and which has been just got in— I continued writing a rambling dissertation, without point, and of which it is doubtful whether I shall ever find a proper use, and I read the remainder of Massillon’s funeral Eulogy upon the Prince de Conti— I had read this and all Massillon’s works before— The Editor of Massillon’s works, says that this Oration was the third of his funeral Eulogies— That it was much applauded when delivered, and much criticised afterwards when printed. There is a tone of declamation against the world, its vanities, its vices and its fashions, in all Massillon’s Eulogies which contrast with the high-flown panegyric upon the Subjects of the discourse, and with the compliments to the persons of their families present to hear him; which give an air of inconsistency, and of hypocrisy to the whole— This Prince of Conti was elected king of Poland in 1697. but Augustus Elector of Saxony supplanted him upon the throne— He was descended from Louis of Bourbon brother to Anthony king of Navarre, father of Henry the 4th.
15. IV:15. Friday.

Mr Harris an Alderman, and Mr Wetmore, a member of the Common Council of Boston, came out as a Sub-committee of the Committee of arrangements appointed by the City Government to take order for the delivery of an Eulogy, of the late Ex-President Monroe— These Gentlemen informed me that it had been determined to invite me to undertake the task— I told them that the relation in which I had stood to Mr Monroe, and the respect that I entertained for his character, would forbid me to decline the invitation, and that the high gratification I should derive from contributing any assistance I could give to an object in which the City Government of Boston took an interest would induce me to undertake the service with pleasure— I then asked them at what time the proposed that the Eulogy should be pronounced— They said they were instructed to enquire what time would best suit my own convenience— I said that in a performance of that Nature a number of biographical notices would be expected for the facts concerning which I should be under the necessity of resorting to the members of Mr Monroe’s family. I should immediately write to his Son in Law, Samuel L. Gouverneur at New-York, and could not anticipate with certainty the time when I might receive his answer—probably in a week or ten days; after which I should want about a fortnight to prepare— I supposed it might be about a Month
before I should be prepared— They said it had been supposed, about three weeks, would be a suitable interval, but that the City Government would readily fix the time which would be convenient to me— I said I would make it as early as possible, and give them notice, as soon as I should be ready— Captain Souther was here to take down a Statement of the property real and personal for which I am liable to be taxed in this Town. I had conversation with him upon the tax I am liable to pay here, and the various kinds of property upon which it is to be levied— I told him I would shortly make out a statement— He said Mr Edward Miller complained of being overtaxed—and that others were undertaxed, and threatened to leave the town, if it should be continued— Mr Lord, of the firm of Richardson and Lord in Boston, was here, and said they had undertaken to print my Oration— The Subcommittee have taken out the copy-right in their own names— Lord promised to send me the proof sheets by Charles, or by the Mail— I wrote to my Son John and to S. L. Gouverneur— Visited the Garden, and rode on horseback after Sunset to the cross roads near Neponset Bridge.
16. IV.45. Saturday.

Isaac Hull went to Boston this morning with Charles and they both returned home to dine— I received a Letter from Mrs Anne Royall, remonstrating against my giving any countenance to Anti-Masonry— Dr Waterhouse came and dined with us, and returned early in the afternoon to Cambridge— He has recently returned from a visit to New-York, where he has a daughter married to a Son of Professor Ware— He met there Doctor Channing of Boston—and mentioned to me the purport of some of his conversations with him— Doctor Channing urged him to write a descriptive account of Rhode-Island, and a biography of the late Portrait Painter, Gilbert Stuart— But he says Stuart’s wife with tears in her eyes intreated him not to do it. The Doctor shewed me a Letter from Mr Madison to whom he had sent a copy of his book upon Junius— A polite Letter, assuring him that the book was very entertaining, but intimating with delicacy, that it has not discovered the Secret— The Doctor asked with some apparent anxiety what was my opinion— I said I thought much like Mr Madison— I said I was unwilling to believe Lord Chatham the author of Junius; because it would lower him in my opinion: but I added I should not be much astonished if positive proof should hereafter appear that he was the man; and then, said I, Doctor, you will pass for a prophet— He made some enquiries of me who was the Earl Temple, the back-stairs man who negotiated with George the third, the rejection by the House of Lords, of the Coalition India-Bill. It turned out to be George Grenville, son of the stupendous calculator of the Stamp-act—but we could not ascertain whether the present Duke of Buckingham was the Son or Grandson of this Earl Temple— Dr Waterhouse compiled a sort of historical novel, from the papers of an American Seaman, confined in Dartmoor prison during the late War, and published it in 1815— He has now thoughts of revising and publishing it again with his own name. I thought it would not now be likely to succeed so well as it did formerly. The subject being now of less general interest— I urged him rather to collect and republish the papers of his controversy concerning his professorship at Harvard University— He took back the Volumes of the Patriot which he had lent me containing those papers— I visited my Garden and Nursery, where the
Walnut seedlings, are yet coming up in considerable numbers— All others have long since ceased to shew themselves— I cut off a twig from my walnut tree of 1804. covered with small caterpillars— They had dissected a neighbouring bough, leaving only skeletons of the leaves— Great part of the day was lost for writing.
17. V. Sunday.

Heard Mr Whitney of Hingham in the morning from Proverbs 16.8. “Better is a little with righteousness, than great Revenues without right.” and in the afternoon, from Romans 13.7. [“]Render therefore to all their dues”— They were both excellent Sermons, that of the morning especially—practical morality adapted to the instruction of his auditory, and far more edifying than controversial speculation, upon the persons of the Trinity or the consequences of the Fall of Man. Mr Whitney is a man of sound sense, and a good writer, though not popular as a preacher, nor captivating by his personal appearance— He dined with us— In the Evening I walked with Charles to Coll. Quincy’s, and spent the Evening there, with him, his wife, and her mother Mrs Miller. While we were there, Mr and Mrs Thomas Greenleaf, and Mr and Mrs Daniel Greenleaf were at our house— I visited my garden and Nursery after dinner, but the progress of my Seedlings has an ounce of disappointment for a scruple of cheering— My health droops, and a languor of dejection creeps upon me— The reception of my 4th. of July rhapsody was as favourable to the auditory, as I could have desired— Publication will bring the Critic, and never in the course of my Life has there been a time when the combination of interests to decry me was so, various and nearly universal as now— Even now too I have assigned to me a task which I could not decline, and to which I am not suited— I must take refuge in my conscience for Consolation—
18. IV:15. Monday. Sun rose 4:37.

Finished my version of the second Psalm; more difficult than any one that I had undertaken—intelligible only by being considered as prophetical of Jesus Christ, and so expressly twice quoted by Saint Paul in the Epistle to the Hebrews 1.5. and 5.5— I felt a repugnance even at attempting it—but the versions of Tate and Watts are both unsatisfactory— Mine is no better but is as good as I could make it— I was occupied from breakfast to dinner time almost entirely in refreshing my Memory upon the important Military Events of our Revolutionary War— Mr Monroe’s career of public life began with it— From 1776 to 1779 he was in General Washington’s Army, and was present at the most important Events in it, through the Series of those years— He was also occasionally engaged in other Military Service till the close of the War— He was wounded by a Ball through the shoulder at the battle of Princeton. It will be indispensable to notice this part of his life in delivering his Eulogy— I must therefore renew my familiarity with the history of the War—for which purpose I read many pages of Pitkin’s and Belsham’s Histories—of Stedman’s History of the War; of the Remembrancer, and of Washington’s Letters to Congress— These gave me distinct recollections of the campaigns of 1776. and of the affair at Princeton in January 1777— Going back to those times seems almost like a resurrection from the dead—but while reading so much I could write but little, and made scarcely any progress with my Eulogy, and otherwise fell in Arrear of my ordinary tasks— Charles borrowed for me at the Athenaeum, and brought out with him Wirt’s
British Spy, written in 1802 when Mr Monroe was Governor of Virginia; in the last Letter of which there is a character of him contrasted with that of Chief Justice Marshall. It is chiefly remarkable as containing a prediction that Mr Monroe would be one day President of the United States— Charles brought me also a message from Mr Ballister, which gave me cause enough for Meditation, and he gave me advice, which ought by me to be pondered still more— I visited my Garden and Nursery and transplanted several wild Cherry and Apple-seedlings from the Book-box to the Garden— My disappointments in these Speculations have this consolation—that they are not very costly— I cannot say the same of others— Black Ants and white lice their offspring, are now the fatal enemies of my Apple Seedlings and perhaps of others— I spent the Evening with Charles at Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s— I received from Richardson Lord and Holbrook, the first proof sheet of my 4th. of July Oration—
19. IV:15. Tuesday.

Began the version of the third Psalm— Charles and his wife left us— He went as usual this morning to Boston, and did not return— His wife went after dinner— Mine took her in the Carriage into town, and came back alone this Evening— They have been here two Months, from the 18th. of May, and have made our residence here very cheerful— But she is expecting to be confined shortly, and they both prefer that this Event should take place in Boston— It is probably a full month distant, but I have forborne to utter a word of interference with their inclinations, in a matter so immediately concerning themselves— If there is a lesson necessary for my peace of mind in this world, it is to form no strong attachment to any person or thing that it contains; and if I have a weakness growing upon me above all others it is that of attaching myself inordinately both to persons and things— To persons from whom I must part— To things which bring me nothing but disappointment— The remnant of my days so far as my physical and intellectual powers will hold out, ought to be devoted to reading and writing, to honour the memory of my father and mother— I suffer numberless things day after day to divert me from them, and whatever I undertake turns to bitter dust and ashes. I spent this morning in writing a few lines of my Eulogy, and in reading the Remembrancer— Genl. Washington’s Official Letters, Pitkin and Stedman, upon the Campaigns of 1777 and 1778. After dinner, I took out from the Library of my father Heath’s Memoirs, two Volumes of Marshall’s life of Washington, and two of Gordon’s History of the American Revolution; I recurred also to the Journals of Congress for the Time when Mr Monroe took his Seat in that body— Our General amused me much this afternoon, but perhaps by absorbing more of my time than I could profitably allow to him— Of the Time when Mr. Monroe took his Seat in Congress, December 1783 at Annapolis, I thought I could avail myself, for some pertinent remarks— I also wrote this afternoon Letters of Introduction for Professor Farrar, to the Duke of Sussex and General La Fayette; and one enclosing them to the Professor— Towards Sunset I bathed with Isaac H. Adams, at the Creek, and swam from wharf to wharf— Elizabeth C. Adams came to spend some days with us— I neglected my visit to my Garden and Nursery, till it was too dark to make any observations—would I could practically see that this is a culpable waste of time— I sent to Richardson, Lord and Holbrook the first proof sheet of my Oration corrected; and received from them the second and third.
20. V. Wednesday

Finished my version of the third Psalm; still with entire dissatisfaction, a Sentiment which hangs upon every thing that I do.— The Psalms appear to a person taking them in hand for translation a series of perpetual repetitions— Yet in every one of them there is some thought not expressed in any other— To seize that is the peculiar duty of the Translator, and as there is in a great many of them an assemblage of ideas the connection between which is not easily perceived, it becomes no easy task, to join upon them the links necessary to form their concatenation— The third Psalm obviously requires the supposition of a lapse of time between the first and last verses— It is said to have been composed by David when he fled before his Son Absalom— But it seems to have been begun when he fled, and finished after the rebellion was subdued— For the first part in an agonizing prayer; and the last a shout of triumph— Unless with this key the Psalm is all inconsistency. With it, the beautiful disorder, is the effect of art— I bathed at the Creek, and swam with Isaac H. Adams immediately after breakfast— Elizabeth went with Mr Gourgas to Boston and returned shortly after dinner— Deacon Spear was here; and has leased my Town river Saltmarsh lot for 17 dollars— The Penny-ferry lot for six— And yesterday set up the Cherry-tree lot at auction; but could get no bid— He is however offered six dollars for it which I consented to take. This afternoon I planted An Atherton last year’s Apple Core and the seeds of another, and also some Strawberry Seeds— I have at last Blackberry vines and currant seedlings from the seeds of last year— A ripening early pear in the centre of the garden— My other Seedlings numerous but devoted to unavoidable destruction— The portion of my Nursery where the wheat was has just been spaded up—but the heat of the Summer forbids my working with the Spade— Professor Farrar sent a Messenger for his Letters and they were given to him— I returned the second and third sheets of my Oration corrected, and received the fourth and fifth, which is the last— I read some pages of the Life of Washington, and wrote one or two of my proposed Eulogy—
21. IV.45. Thursday.

Began my version of the fourth Psalm, and sent the last two half sheets of my Oration to the printers in Boston— I went in with John Kirke myself and attended a Meeting of the ФB.K. Society, which had been called by Edward Everett their President, by an Advertisement in the Newspapers— I was surprized to find assembled at the Hall of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences between fifty and sixty Members— The President soon after I entered called the Meeting to order and stated his object in calling it—which was to consider the propriety of revising the charter and fundamental Laws of the Society; which he read— He read also that part of a recent publication of Avery Allyn upon Free-Masonry, which relates to the Ф.B.K. Society—and in which an account in some respects erroneous of the Origin and character of the Institution is given— And he further read a Letter to him from William Short now at Philadelphia. William Short was the first signer at William and Mary College, Virginia, of the Charter of the Ф.B.K. society at Harvard University— This Charter was granted to Elisha Parmele in 1779: and in the Statutes of the Institution there is the form of an Oath to be administered to every member at his admission. Short says the Society was formed by a fellow Student of his at the College of Williamsburg, because he prided himself in being the first Hellenist of the College, and that it was to rivalise another Society with Latin initials— After these Papers I enquired what other branches of the Society were known to exist at this Time
with a view to propose some communication with them before adopting any definitive measure— Judge Story moved that a Committee should be appointed to take the charter and Laws of the Society into Consideration, and report a revision of them to the Society at an adjoint Meeting. While the Judge was reducing his Motion to writing, I offered one, not to supersede his but to be adopted with it— I enquired if the elections were already completed, of the Members of the Class now passing from the Junior to the Senior Class— Nobody knew; but it was believed that part of them were chosen, and the rest remained to be elected— I moved a Resolution that no Oath should be administered to any Member of the Society to be hereafter elected, and no promise of secrecy required— Judge Story withdrew his motion to allow mine to be debated— Many amendments were proposed to my motion, which were debated at least two hours— No direct opposition to it was avowed—but substitutes and Amendments rapidly succeeded one another, and the debate was running into a snarl— Franklin Dexter at last proposed as an Amendment to my Resolution, that no Secret should be disclosed to any member to be admitted hereafter— I accepted it as a part of my Motion deeming it a mere verbal addition, signifying nothing, but it raised a fourfold array of objections, and my motion was finally voted to be laid on the Table— Judge Story’s motion was then taken up and after some discussion adopted— He moved that the Committee should consist of nine, and be nominated by the President, which was agreed to. The Committee are Judge Story, J. Q. Adams, H. H. Fuller, Dr. Lowell, A. H. Everett, C. G. Loring, L. Baldwin, J. T. Austin, and Judge C Jackson— I then moved that the form of Oath in the Record Book should be repealed, to which J. T. Austin objected as not in order, after the appointment of the Committee and the President so divided— But Mr Loring moved that no new member should be admitted till after the Committee shall have reported, and that vote passed— It is now vacation at the College so that none can be admitted— The Meeting adjourned to Thursday the 11th. of next Month, and Judge Story notified the members of the Committee to meet next Monday Morning at ten. We adjourned at half past one— The views of Judge Story extend to a total remodeling of the Society—to abolish the rule requiring unanimity, at the election of the Members, and to turn the Society into an Academy of Literature— He declared his disapprobation of all secret Societies, and declared the Administration of the Oath illegal— As I returned from the Meeting to Charles’s Office, I met before it Judge Hall, who went in there with me for a few minutes, and then to the Judge’s House where he insisted upon giving me a box of Lee’s antibilious pills— I went to Charles’s House, and saw his wife— He was not at home— I returned to Quincy to dine. Evening walk in Garden and Nursery— The walnuts have come up in numbers, but they and all the other seedlings droop— Some die, I know not how or why— Mr Gourgas was here in the Evening— Shower— Distant Thunder.
22. IV.15. Friday— Sun rose 4:41.

Finished the version of the 4th. Psalm— Mr Curtis and Mrs Boylston were here perhaps two hours this morning— Mr Curtis shewed me a Letter with a proposal to purchase two lots of Mr Boylston’s Princeton Estate; and a Letter from Mr Cutler concerning the Eastern Lands— Mrs Boylston had a certificate of good conduct and Scholarship, from the Preceptor of the Leicester Academy for Ward— She said Thomas never would make a Scholar and she thought
ought not to be sent to the University— Ward will be prepared to enter at the ensuing Commencement, and Mrs Boylston appeared undetermined whether it would be best that he should reside and board in the College, or abroad in the Town— I inclined to consult with Mr Quincy the President upon the Subject— Mr Curtis and Mrs Boylston, proposed to settle an Account of the Executors, at the Probate Office here next Month, and engaged to dine with us on Tuesday the 9th. of August—the day on which will hold the Court— Mr and Mrs Barrell afterwards paid us a visit of perhaps two hours— Mr Gourgas dined with us. After dinner I visited my Garden and Nursery, which lose their attractions, I wish I could say entirely— I received from Richardson Lord and Holbrook six printed Copies of my Oration— I walked to my brother’s and gave his wife one of them.
23. IV:45. Saturday.

Began my version of the 5th. Psalm— Received this morning a Letter from Samuel L. Gouverneur, and a manuscript of 250 pages containing an Auto-biography of Mr Monroe, coming down only from his birth to the time of his return from his first mission to France— This manuscript will essentially serve me for the composition of my Eulogy; which is excruciating— I answered Mr Gouverneur’s Letter, and wrote also to R. Rush, enclosing to him a copy of my Oration— I had also a Letter from Mr George Johnson of Alexandria, now at the Tremont house in Boston, and who wishes to execute with me an agreement for an exchange of Lots in Square 231. Washington. I answered his Letter promising to meet him at my Son Charles’s Office next Monday Morning at half past nine. These Letters absorbed so much of the day, that I wrote not a line of Eulogy, but I bathed and swam from wharf to wharf with I. H. Adams— Noah Curtis and his Son Adam were here this afternoon— Adam came to bargain for a house lot on my land at the foot of Penns hill, for a young man working with him named Crane— He had sent E. Turner to me to ask my price for half an Acre which I had named— He now wished, not to reduce the price but the quantity, and I agreed to convey 1/3 of an Acre for 400 dollars— The young man wishes to build immediately, and I agreed to apply to Mr Humphrey, to survey the lot next Tuesday— Walk in the garden towards dusk— A few of the large Shagbarks from Washington which I planted 16. May are coming up.— They shoot up a stem as much as three inches long before putting out their leaves.
24. V:15. Sunday.

Heard Mr Whitney, in the Morning from Isaiah 43.13 [“]Yea, before the day was, I am he; and there is none that can deliver out of my hand: I will work, and who shall let it?” and in the afternoon from Mark 4.26 “And he said, so is the kingdom of God, as if a man should cast seed into the ground; 27. And should sleep, and rise night and day, and the seed should spring and grow up, he knoweth not how. 28 For the Earth bringeth forth fruit of herself: first the blade, then the ear, after that the full Corn in the Ear.” The parables about raising plants from the seed have a significancy to me, since I have attempted the practice myself which they never possessed before— Their literal sense strikes me more than the figurative— This casting seed into the ground, sleeping, and rising Night and day; witnessing the springing up and growth of the plant without knowing how, is picturesque of my own condition— William Field’s wife was prayed for—dying of a Consumption. Towards Evening I rode with Mrs Adams over to
Weymouth and after numerous enquiries found to my great surprize Mr Humphrey residing in the old house which was formerly Dr Tufts’s, one of the houses where once my careless childhood stray’d—more than 25 years had passed since I was in the house, and I cannot describe the Sensation with which I now entered it— All is changed around me— Of my cotemporaries how few remain— Of my Seniors scarce any yet how vain and profitless the reflection incessantly pressed upon me that a few short days only can pass, before I must follow my fathers to the grave, and leave my dwelling to I know not whom— Mr Humphrey promised to come over to Quincy and survey my lot next Tuesday between one and two, unless it should rain, and in that case on Thursday— We returned home over the Bent’s point Bridge, and on the way I passed by the grave-yard where fifty-five years since I saw my mother’s Mother deposited— She had been a second mother to me, and my memory never recurs to her but with a feeling of melancholy affection.— Death fixes forever the relation existing between the departed Spirit and the Survivors upon Earth— My Grandmother Smith can never be to me any other than a guardian Angel of my Childhood; nor I to her other than a child of her guardian care— I cannot realize that I am now seven years older than she was when she died, nor conceive that if we meet in heaven it must be under very different relations than those in which we were separated by her death— After my return home, Mr G. W. Beale, Coll. Quincy and Mr Gourgas spent the Evening with us— Mr T. Greenleaf sent me some Madelain or Citron des Carmes and some English Jeanneton Pears.
25. V. Monday.

Finished my version of the 5th. Psalm— I went into Boston early this Morning with my wife. Met at half past nine, Mr George Johnson at my Son Charles’s Office, and executed with him the Articles of Agreement for the exchange of Lots in Square 231. by deed to be executed next Winter at Washington— Charles was not yet at his Office. I went into the Street, and found there Sheriff C. P. Sumner, and Dr George Parkman, who went up with me and witnessed the Execution of the Deeds— I then went immediately to the Hall of the American Academy, and there met the ФBK Committee, judge Story presiding— We there discussed for four hours the report to be made to the Society— After much desultory discussion—I moved that the Committee should report a Resolution repealing all parts of the Charter and Laws which require the Administration of an Oath, and any promise of Secrecy— This after much discussion was adopted, Coll. Baldwin only voting against it— He preferred to continue the Society as it is, and wished for no change— A proposition was then made to alter the rule requiring unanimity for the election of members, and after some desultory debate Mr A. H. Everett moved that in future members should be elected by a vote of two thirds of the members present— I opposed this alteration, first upon the ground that I thought no other alteration of the Charter and Laws necessary, than that which had been adopted, and secondly because the rule requiring unanimity for the choice of members depended upon that part of the Institution which declared one of its great objects to be Friendship. I finally moved as an Amendment to Everett’s Resolution, that all the parts of the Charter and Laws, which have any relation to Friendship should be repealed; leaving it a mere literary Association— This was rejected by a vote of five to three and Everett’s Resolution passed by the same vote— Austin was gone— Another Resolution was then proposed and passed
that all nominations for election of members but of under graduates should be made a year before-hand— I then objected to any further alterations, believing that we had already more than matter enough for one day’s debate of the Society— A Sub-Committee of three, judge Story, A. H. Everett and judge Jackson, was then appointed to report a revised Constitution and Code, at an adjourned Meeting of the Committee on Monday the 8th. of next Month— I gave Judge Story a copy of my Oration— He said he had delivered eight Lectures of his course at Cambridge against Nullification and Blackstone’s definition of Sovereignty. He said he proposed to publish his Lectures next year, and should cite me as authority for his doctrine— He said too he was glad I had named Massachusetts as one of the States which had countenanced the absurdity of nullification— It was two O’Clock, when the Committee adjourned— I called at Charles’s house, and then went and dined with Dr George Parkman— The Roman Catholic Bishop Fenwick Francis Parkman, F. C. Gray were there, and other company not of my acquaintance— After dinner I returned to Charles’s house, and thence in the Evening to Quincy— We had taken John’s child Louisa with us.
26. V:15. Tuesday

Began the version of the 6th. Psalm, and resumed writing of the Eulogy. All the Morning was showery, with Thunder and Lightening. It continued beyond the Time when Mr Humphrey had agreed to meet me at the foot of Penn’s Hill, and the Lot was of course not surveyed. William Spear called, and I desired him to view my Cherry-tree lot of Salt-marsh to ascertain the cost of fencing it— He has cut, carted and brought to my house 13 Cords of Pine and hard wood, from the two Lots reserved last November from Minot Thayer’s sale— I have had the lower part of my Nursery where Thayer’s wheat has been growing laid out in beds, for planting Nuts, seeds and seedling Plants— I was taking a short walk, and met a boy from Captain Underwood, an inhabitant of Quincy, just from New-York; he gave me a New-York Evening Post of yesterday, which he said the Captain had sent me because it contained news from Washington— Immediately afterwards I met Mr Seaver who was coming to my house, with fifty Copies of my Oration— I had received fifty before— Seaver told me the terms upon which Richardson Lord and Holbrook had purchased the Copy-right which is taken out in the name of the members of the Sub-Committee— They give them three hundred copies, one hundred of which they have presented to me— Then they give five Cents a copy for the first two thousand copies, four Cents a copy for the third thousand, three Cents for the fourth thousand, and two Cents a copy for every subsequent thousand— Seaver said he had received the three hundred furnished to the Committee, and that every one of them was gone— It has hitherto been received by the public as well as it was by the auditory, for which I would be duly grateful, as I am now to pass through an ordeal far more severe— The Evening Post, contained an Address from John M. Berrien late Attorney General of the United States to the Public, with much collateral Correspondence. The Telegraph newspaper some time since affirmed that a member of Congress had last Winter called at the request of the President upon The Secretaries of the Treasury, of the Navy, and the Attorney General and informed them that unless their families would associate with Mrs Eaton, they would be removed— This was first faintly and afterwards positively denied to be true in the Globe Newspaper— A tart correspondence ensued between Berrien, and Blair the Editor of the Globe extremely insolent and insulting on the part of Blair, till Blair finally produced extracts from a Paper which he affirmed the President had read to the two Secretaries, and Attorney General as declaratory of his intentions— The purport of it was that if he had Evidence that there was a combination to drive Major Eaton from his Cabinet, it would be considered of— This Paper Berrien and Ingham positively declare never was read to them.
They both declare that Richard M. Johnson did come to them on the 26th. of January last and inform them and Branch, that the President had determined to remove them from Office unless they would invite Mrs Eaton to their large parties— Blair produces an extract from a Letter of Richard M. Johnson, stating that the President had expressly disclaimed any intention to interfere with their family concerns, and declares himself expressly authorised to say that the President did read the paper to them— Ingham says Johnson told him that the President was under such excitement that he was like a roaring Lion; and that Huygens the Dutch Minister’s wife had joined in the conspiracy against Mrs Eaton, and that he would send Huygens home to teach him and his master that the wife of a member of his Cabinet should not be treated so— And that afterwards the President repeated in substance the same thing to him— The private morals of the Country were deeply outraged by the Appointment of Eaton to an Office of Cabinet Minister, and they are vindicating themselves by a tremendous re-action— But what else could be expected from a President of the United States himself an adjudicated Adulterer.
27. V. Wednesday.
