My Diary has fallen several days in arrear, and I have difficulty to retrieve it especially with my time so much absorbed in the composition of my Eulogy— Time flies with inconceivable rapidity, and my own labours seem to be little more than the idleness of the Sluggard— Mr Seaver who is one of the Town School masters invited me to attend the Meeting of the Norfolk Association of Teachers at four O’Clock this afternoon at the Town Hall, which I did— Mr Storrs the Minister of Braintree delivered an Address, which was followed by another from Mr Rider, a School-master at Dorchester—and the Constitution of the Society was read by Mr Ibrahim Bartlett, master at the Stone School-house— A prayer was also made by Mr Potter the Minister of the Episcopal Church— There was some singing and some speaking by the small girls of Mr Seaver’s School— The Hall was nearly filled with Ladies and with the Children of the School— The men were few—among them Mr Marston and Mr Daniel Greenleaf— I went thence to my brother’s and found there his daughter Mrs Angier, and her husband’s brother Joseph. My brother himself continues exceedingly unwell, and is fallen away to a degree that gives me great concern.
28. IV.30— Thursday.

Finished my version of the 6th. Psalm. At half past one I met Mr Humphrey, and Adam Curtis at the foot of Penn’s Hill; where the front of a lot for Crane was laid off five Rods and one third, with depth to make the lot one third of an Acre— My project was to lay off in house lots of nearly the same dimensions the whole space between the School-House, and Henry Hardwick’s House; but after some consideration we concluded that it would be best to lay it off first upon the plan, and then correspondingly upon the ground— We are to meet again for that purpose next Wednesday 3d. of August, at four in the afternoon— Returning home I walked over the hills and visited some of my Trees— Found a large swarm of Caterpillar worms Upon the Shagbark tree which bore considerably last year— I saw but one nut upon it now— The wild Pear trees are in bearing. The Ash, loaded with seeds last year has none now— The large black Oak, which had no Acorns last year has now a few— The unknown bears its berries full, now as it did last year— The ground is spungy with rain— Nuts few.
On my return home, I found judge Hall, and his eldest Son here. They had come out from Boston, for a visit of civility; and on the part of the judge, of acknowledgment for the copy of my Oration which I had sent him— Mr Lord, the Printer of the Oration sometime afterwards came in— He said he understood I was engaged in writing a biography of my father; and that his house were desirous of being the publishers of it— I said it was doubtful whether such a work would be published in my life-time—but if it should, I would remember his proposals and confer with him upon the subject— I told him there was an Autobiography of my father containing an account of a considerable portion of his life, and fragments of Journals which all together would fill two large Octavo Volumes— That I should perhaps publish them and part of his Correspondence, in which case I would apply to him— He then spoke of the Oration and of its success— Said he had printed at first two thousand copies; and then two thousand more; and that they were all gone— He had sent small parcels of them to all the Southern Cities, and to several parts of the Western Country— He spoke of a critical contest of a fact stated in the Oration, contained in the Boston daily advertiser of yesterday which I had seen— Mr G. W. Beale, and Augustus and Caroline Whitney were here this Evening— Mr Beale recommended a man named Robertson who lives with him to take my farm next year—
29. IV. Friday.

Began the version of the 7th. Psalm. William Spear was here, and I settled with him for his cutting, cording and carting my wood— He told me that I should have half of eighty three Rods of fencing to make, at my Cherry tree lot of Salt marsh, and that it would cost me a dollar a lot— I get six dollars for the crop of Salt hay upon it this year— The heavy crops of grass this and the three last preceding Summers has depreciated the value of Salt-meadow and salt hay almost to nothing— Mr and Mrs. Brooks of Hingham, and Anna Thaxter paid us an afternoon visit— I strolled in my garden and Nursery which have become objects of painful disappointment to me— Of my planted Seedlings about one in fifty come up; and of these it is doubtful to me, whether one in fifty will live— They perish by the Sun, by the rain, by frosts, by insects; and multitudes I know not how or why— I now see them dying daily. I found nevertheless this day Strawberry Vines up from 12 whole Strawberries, which I planted in White Pot N. 1. on the 11th. of June— I have also Thimbleberry Vines, Blackberry Vines and Currant shoots up from Seeds sown last Summer— I have taken up one Blackberry vine and set it out in the Garden where it is growing not very rapidly— All my Strawberries take root and spread— Those from the Railway Rocks more luxuriantly than any others, but they have not blossomed— My Oak seedlings are all failing. They grow with extreme irregularity; and the stems of many of them come up twisting round like a corkscrew— Peaches shoot up the most thriftily— I have now some of them nearly three feet high, the growth of this Spring and Summer.
30. V. Saturday.

Finished reading the Apocrypha— I have never been able to form an exact idea of the Chronology of the Books of the Maccabees— The second is professedly an abridgment of a history in five Books by Jason of Cyrene— It ends at the same time as the 7th. Chapter of the first Book— There is something very peculiar in the character of the apocryphal Books— The Book of Ecclesiasticus I have always admired, and think it little inferior to the Proverbs. Perhaps imitation of them— The wisdom of Solomon is in yet higher repute— I think better of it at this reading than I ever did before— The rest seem to be not worth much. There is a kind of composition in them all, differing both from that of the Old, and
that of the new Testament— The books are all in Greek, and their Style resembles that of the profane Greek writers more than any of the books of the New Testament. The period of which the Books of the Maccabees treat is that immediately succeeding the age of Alexander the Great— This is nearly two centuries later than any of the other Books— My wife went into Boston this Morning to spend a week or ten days with our Son Charles and his wife; Mrs Frothingham having been confined yesterday with a daughter— Mrs Nowlan went also into Boston, intending to return here to-morrow— I discovered this morning in the border of the front yard opposite my Chamber Window, a Seedling Walnut from the large Shagbarks which I brought from Washington; and also some Strawberry Vines up in a glass Tumbler, from white Strawberries which I planted in June— I bathed and swam this Morning with my Nephew Isaac H. Adams; and walked this Evening to my brothers— He is yet much indisposed.
31. IV:30. Sunday— Sun rose 4:50. Began reading of the New Testament.

Heard Mr Brooks of Hingham, in the morning from Matthew 6.10. “Thy kingdom come”—and in the afternoon from Matthew 23.37. “O, Jerusalem, Jerusalem, thou that killest the prophets, and stonest them which are sent unto thee, how often would I have gathered thy children together, as a hen, gathereth her chickens under her wings, and ye would not. 38. Behold, your house is left unto you desolate.” This latter discourse contained some observations upon the extraordinary influence exercised by the Jewish Nation over the world of mankind— It is a copious and interesting topic, upon which much is to be said— Mr Brooks, barely broached it— Nothing can be more surprizing to mere worldly meditation; and that is one of the cogent arguments for the holy inspiration of the Scriptures— I think Mr Brooks abridged his discourse at the prospect of a thundergust— On the same account he dismissed the Congregation omitting the last singing. It saved me a drenching; for as it was I reached home without wetting; but I had not been half a minute in the house before the rain came down in torrents; and there was the heaviest thundergust by far that we have had this season— It returned several times, and there was one clap like the discharge of a cannon close under your inspection. Mrs Nowlan returned in the Carriage from Boston.

Day. I had not even completed the revisal of my fourth of July Oration for the press, when the application came from the corporation of Boston, to deliver an Eulogy upon Mr Monroe which I had scarcely the right, and could not have the inclination to decline— But it has from that time oppressed me with reading and writing almost night and day, in the heart of a Summer damp and sultry beyond example— And I have been not less oppressed with anxiety than with labour— The Oration succeeded far beyond expectation and has been hitherto spared very generally by malignant criticism— Non nobis domine sed nomini tuo sit gloria— It touched upon popular topics, and presented them under new views— This I cannot again do, nor can I do Justice to the subject without coming in collision with Passions and Resentments which will not sleep— There is a combination of parties against me including almost the whole population of the Country, and of which my former supporters are the most inveterate— The Clay Masons, and so called National Republicans— This Eulogy will furnish them an occasion to assail me— I now employ the day from morning dawn till dark in reading and writing, and all other business runs in arrear—
